summary: By now, every state has passed legislation modeled after New York’s Married Women’s Property Act (1848), granting married women some control over their property and earnings.

Muller v State of Oregon, 208 U.S. 412 (1908): The U.S. Supreme Court upholds Oregon’s 10-hour workday for women. The win is a two-edged sword: the protective legislation implies that women are physic

Margaret Sanger tests the validity of New York’s anti-contraception law by establishing a clinic in Brooklyn. The most well-known of birth control advocates, she is one of hundreds arrested over a 40-
Jeanette Rankin of Montana is elected the first woman member of the U.S. House of representatives.

New York v. Sanger, 222 NY 192, 118 N.E. 637 (Court of Appeals 1917), National Archives, Records of the U.S. Supreme Court, RG 267 (MSDME-CDS C 15:298). Margaret Sanger wins her suit in New York to al
The Nineteenth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution is ratified. It declares: “The right of citizens of the United States to vote shall not be denied or abridged by the United States or by any State on
Florence Ellinwood Allen of Ohio becomes the first woman elected to a state supreme court.
National Woman’s Party proposes Constitutional amendment: “Men and women shall have equal rights throughout the United States and in every place subject to its jurisdiction. Congress shall have power
Radice v. New York, a New York state case, upholds a law that forbade waitresses from working the night shift but made an exception for entertainers and ladies’ room attendants.
Genevieve Rose Cline of Ohio becomes the first woman to be a federal judge.
United States v. One Package of Japanese Pessaries, 13 F. Supp.334 (E.D.N.Y 1936) aff’d 86 F 2d 737 (2nd Cir. 1936), won judicial approval of medicinal use of birth control.
The U.S. Supreme Court upholds Washington state’s minimum wage laws for women.
The United Nations establishes the Commission on the Status of Women to safeguard women’s rights and oversee their global status.
Fay v. New York, 332 U.S. 261 (1947), the U.S. Supreme Court says women are equally qualified with men to serve on juries but are granted an exemption and may serve or not as women choose.
Women’s Paycheck Act (California)
Emma Baker is the first woman to receive a Ph.D. from a Canadian university.
On January 29, women in Manitoba become the first in Canada to vote in a provincial election.
Some women were granted the right to vote in federal elections.
Agnes Macphail is the first woman elected to the House of Commons
Canada’s court defines women as “persons” in the Persons Case.
Decriminalization of same-sex intimacy for consenting adults.
Report on the Royal Commission on the Status of Women tabled in Parliament.
Position of Minister for Status of Women created.
Office of the Coordinator, Status of Women, becomes federal agency.
Roberta Jamieson becomes the first Indigenous woman in Canada to earn a law degree.
Canadian Human Rights Act passed, ensuring equal pay and forbidding sex discrimination.
Immigration Act amended to remove homosexuality as inadmissibility.
Persons Day is celebrated, marking 50th anniversary of the Persons Case.
Canada ratifies UN CEDAW convention.
Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms includes 'sex' as protected ground.
Bill C-127 makes sexual assault in marriage a crime.
Bill C-31 reinstates Indian status for women who lost it via marriage.
National Day of Remembrance and Action on Violence Against Women established.
October designated as Women’s History Month in Canada.
Canadian Forces ends service restrictions on LGBTQ.
Kim Campbell becomes first (and only) female Prime Minister of Canada.
Federal Plan for Gender Equality and Employment Equity Act come into force.
Canada adopts Beijing Declaration on gender equality and rights.
Supreme Court extends equality rights to sexual orientation.
Human Rights Act amended to protect sexual orientation.
Benefits and Obligations Act includes same-sex couples.
Human Rights Commission recommends proactive pay equity system.
Standing Committee on Status of Women established in Parliament.
Same-sex marriage becomes legal across Canada.
Nadine Caron becomes first Indigenous General Surgeon in Canada.
First Trans March held in Toronto Pride.
Gender Equity in Indian Registration Act (Bill C-3) receives royal assent.
UN adopts International Day of the Girl under Canada's leadership.
First full Minister of Status of Women appointed federally.
Cabinet becomes gender-balanced for the first time.
National Inquiry into Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls launched.
2SLGBTQI+ Secretariat created.
Gender identity & expression protected in Human Rights Act (Bill C-16).
Canada launches first federal GBV Strategy: “Itʼs Time”.
Formal apology for purge of LGBTQ2 persons from RCMP, military, civil service.
Interim report released by Inquiry on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women.
LGBT Purge Class Action Settlement Agreement approved.
Historical unjust convictions expunged.
Canada launches Feminist International Assistance Policy.
Gender Equality Week launched in September.
Gender Budgeting Act passed.
WAGE Canada legislated as full department.
Pay Equity Act passed for public service fairness.
Bill S-3 ends remaining Indian Act sex-based inequities.
Outdated sexual offences repealed.
LGBTQ2-targeted funding programs launched.
Final report on Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women released.
Karen Jensen named first Pay Equity Commissioner.
National Strategy to Combat Human Trafficking launched.
Gender parity reached in Senate.
Canada includes transgender and non-binary data in Census.
Mary Simon appointed first Indigenous Governor General.
RoseAnne Archibald becomes first female AFN National Chief.
Cassidy Caron elected first female Métis National Council President.
Joint Declaration for Canada Free of Gender-Based Violence signed.
50-30 Corporate Diversity Challenge launched.
Conversion therapy officially banned.
Bill C-25 mandates corporate diversity disclosure.
Canada launches Federal 2SLGBTQI+ Action Plan.
Blood donation screening no longer excludes based on gender/sexuality.
Mexican women gained the right to divorce, and gradually, rights to alimony and child custody were recognized.
The First Feminist Congress was held in Yucatán, advocating for educational equality and equal pay in the Constitution.
During the Mexican Revolution, female 'Soldaderas' fought in battle and served in logistics and healthcare, becoming national symbols.
Yucatán became the first state to grant women the right to vote. Elvia Carrillo Puerto and two others were elected to the state legislature but later forced to resign.
On October 17, the Mexican Constitution was amended to grant women the right to vote and run for office at the national level.
On July 3, women voted in federal elections for the first time, electing the 43rd Chamber of Deputies.
María Lavalle Urbina became the first female president of the Mexican Senate and represented Mexico on the UN Commission on the Status of Women.
Griselda Álvarez became the governor of Colima, the first female governor in Mexican history.
Mexico's Supreme Court ruled that criminalizing abortion is unconstitutional, paving the way for nationwide legalization.
